div.p: We construct universal twists connecting the centrally extended double Yangian ğ’Ÿâ¢Yâ¢(sâ¢lâ¢(2))cğ’Ÿğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘™2ğ‘caligraphic-D italic-Y OPEN:( italic-s italic-l OPEN:( NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y}(sl(2))_{c} with deformed double Yangians ğ’Ÿâ¢Yrâ¢(sâ¢lâ¢(2))cğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘™2ğ‘caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s italic-l OPEN:( NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}}(sl(2))_{c}, thereby establishing the quasi-Hopf structures of the latter.

p.span: On the quasi-Hopf structure of deformed double Yangians

D. Arnaudonağ‘FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-a FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{a}, J. Avanbğ‘FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-b FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{b}, L. div.p: MSC number: 81R50, 17B37
LAPTH-773/00
PAR-LPTHE 00-01
math.QA/0001034
January 2000

Universal twists connecting (affine) quantum groups to (elliptic) (dynamical) (affine) algebras have been constructed in [1, 2, 3]. They show in particular the quasi-Hopf structure of elliptic and dynamical algebras. These twists transform the universal Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrix â„›â„›caligraphic-R{\cal R} of the first object into the universal Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrix â„›â„±superscriptâ„›â„±caligraphic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal R}^{\cal F} of the second one as follows:

semantics.annotation: caligraphic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:21 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end caligraphic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

div.p: The double degeneracy limits of elliptic Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrices, whether vertex-type [4, 5, 6] or face-type [7] give rise to algebraic structures which have been variously characterised as scaled elliptic algebras [5, 6], or double Yangian algebras [7, 8, 9]. As pointed out earlier [4, 6]111We wish to thank S.Â Pakuliak for clarifying this point to us., although represented by formally identical Yangâ€“Baxter relations Râ¢Lâ¢L=Lâ¢Lâ¢Rğ‘…ğ¿ğ¿ğ¿ğ¿ğ‘…italic-R italic-L italic-L RELOP:equals italic-L italic-L italic-RRLL=LLR [10], these two classes of objects differ fundamentally in their structures (as is reflected in the very different mode expansions of Lğ¿italic-LL defining their individual generators) and must be considered separately.

In our previous paper [7] we have defined, in the quantum inverse scattering or RLL formulation, various algebraic structures of double Yangian type connected by twist-like operators, i.e. such that their evaluated Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrices were related as:

semantics.annotation: italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:21 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: for a particular matrix Fğ¹italic-FF. It was conjectured that these twist-like operators were indeed evaluation representations of universal twists obeying a shifted cocycle condition thereby raising the relation (1.2) to the status of a genuine twist connection (1.1) between quasi-Hopf algebras.

We shall be concerned here only with algebraic structures related to the algebra sâ¢lâ¢(2)^csubscript^ğ‘ ğ‘™2ğ‘OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-s italic-l OPEN:( NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\widehat{sl(2)}_{c}, and henceforth dispense with indicating it explicitly: for instance ğ’Ÿâ¢Yğ’Ÿğ‘Œcaligraphic-D italic-Y{{\cal D}Y} is thus to be understood as ğ’Ÿâ¢Yâ¢(sâ¢lâ¢(2)^c)ğ’Ÿğ‘Œsubscript^ğ‘ ğ‘™2ğ‘caligraphic-D italic-Y OPEN:( OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-s italic-l OPEN:( NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:){{\cal D}Y}{(\widehat{sl(2)}_{c})}.

It is our purpose here to establish such connections, at the level of universal Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrices, between the double Yangian structures respectively known as ğ’Ÿâ¢Yğ’Ÿğ‘Œcaligraphic-D italic-Y{{\cal D}Y}, ğ’Ÿâ¢YrVâ¢6ğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ‘‰6caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6}}, ğ’Ÿâ¢YrVâ¢8ğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ‘‰8caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V8}} and ğ’Ÿâ¢YrFğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ¹caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{F}}. ğ’Ÿâ¢Yğ’Ÿğ‘Œcaligraphic-D italic-Y{{\cal D}Y} is the double Yangian defined in [9, 11]. ğ’Ÿâ¢YrVâ¢6ğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ‘‰6caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6}} is characterised by a scaled â€œellipticâ€ Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrix defined in [4], ğ’Ÿâ¢YrVâ¢8ğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ‘‰8caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V8}} is characterised by a scaled Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrix defined in [6, 5]. In connection with our previous caveat, note that these Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrices are also used to describe respectively the scaled elliptic algebras ğ’œâ„,0subscriptğ’œPlanck-constant-over-2-pi0caligraphic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal A}_{\hbar,0}, ğ’œâ„,Î·subscriptğ’œPlanck-constant-over-2-piğœ‚caligraphic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi PUNCT:, italic-eta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal A}_{\hbar,\eta} [5, 6, 4]. ğ’Ÿâ¢YrFğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ¹caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{F}} is the deformed double Yangian obtained by a particular limit of the dynamical Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrix characterising elliptic â„¬q,p,Î»subscriptâ„¬ğ‘ğ‘ğœ†caligraphic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q PUNCT:, italic-p PUNCT:, italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{{\cal B}_{q,p,\lambda}} algebra [7].

A crucial ingredient for our procedure is a linear (difference) equation obeyed by the twist. This type of equation for twist operators was first written in [12]. It is also present in [2, 3]. Our method consists in i) finding a twist-like action in representation ii) interpreting this representation as an infinite product iii) defining a linear equation obeyed by this infinite product iv) promoting this linear equation for the representation to the level of linear equation for universal twist. v) The solution of this linear equation is obtained as a infinite product as in [2] which vi) is then proved to obey the shifted cocycle condition as in [2, 3] and vii) has an evaluation representation identical to the twist-like action found in i).

This provides us with the universal Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrix and quasi-Hopf structure of the twisted algebras ğ’Ÿâ¢YrVâ¢6,Vâ¢8,Fğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ‘‰6ğ‘‰8ğ¹caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 PUNCT:, italic-V NUMBER:8 PUNCT:, italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6,V8,F}}, thereby realising a fully consistent description of these algebraic structures.

The universal Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrix and Hopf algebra structure for ğ’Ÿâ¢Yğ’Ÿğ‘Œcaligraphic-D italic-Y{{\cal D}Y} were described in [9, 11]. We construct a universal twist between ğ’Ÿâ¢Yğ’Ÿğ‘Œcaligraphic-D italic-Y{{\cal D}Y} and ğ’Ÿâ¢YrVâ¢6ğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ‘‰6caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6}}. We then show the existence of a universal coboundary (trivial) twist, the evaluation of which realises the connection between the evaluated Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrices of ğ’Ÿâ¢YrVâ¢6ğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ‘‰6caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6}} and ğ’Ÿâ¢YrVâ¢8ğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ‘‰8caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V8}}, leading to identification of these two as quasi-Hopf algebras. Finally another universal coboundary-like twist realises, when evaluated, the connection between the Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrices of ğ’Ÿâ¢YrVâ¢6ğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ‘‰6caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6}} and ğ’Ÿâ¢YrFğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ¹caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{F}}.
It follows that the three deformed structures are in fact one single quasi-Hopf algebra described by three different choices of generators, more precisely given in three different gauges.

We shall denote throughout this paper â„±â¢[ğ’œ;â„¬]â„±ğ’œâ„¬caligraphic-F OPEN:[ caligraphic-A PUNCT:; caligraphic-B CLOSE:]{{\cal F}}[{{\cal A}}\,;{{\cal B}}] the universal or represented twist connecting Rğ‘…italic-RR-matrices as â„›â„¬=â„±21â¢[ğ’œ;â„¬]â¢â„›ğ’œâ¢â„±12-1â¢[ğ’œ;â„¬]subscriptâ„›â„¬subscriptâ„±21ğ’œâ„¬subscriptâ„›ğ’œsuperscriptsubscriptâ„±121ğ’œâ„¬caligraphic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start caligraphic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:21 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:[ caligraphic-A PUNCT:; caligraphic-B CLOSE:] caligraphic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start caligraphic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:[ caligraphic-A PUNCT:; caligraphic-B CLOSE:]{{\cal R}}_{{{\cal B}}}={{\cal F}}_{21}[{{\cal A}}\,;{{\cal B}}]\;{{\cal R}}_{% {{\cal A}}}\;{{\cal F}}_{12}^{-1}[{{\cal A}}\,;{{\cal B}}].

Note that this case is similar to the gauge transformation used in [15] although gğ‘”italic-gg is not purely Cartan.
It follows that

div.p:
satisfies the shifted Yangâ€“Baxter equation (4.11).
To recover (5.1), use (5.5) and remark that Ï€xâŠ—Ï€xâ¢(gâŠ—g)tensor-productsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¥subscriptğœ‹ğ‘¥tensor-productğ‘”ğ‘”italic-pi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:tensor-product italic-pi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-g MULOP:tensor-product italic-g CLOSE:)\pi_{x}\otimes\pi_{x}(g\otimes g) commutes with Râ¢[ğ’Ÿâ¢Y]ğ‘…delimited-[]ğ’Ÿğ‘Œitalic-R OPEN:[ caligraphic-D italic-Y CLOSE:]R[{{\cal D}Y}].

{\cal K}_{12}(r)\;(\Delta^{\cal F}\otimes\mbox{id}){\cal K}(r)={\cal K}_{23}(r% +c^{(1)})\;(\mbox{id}\otimes\Delta^{{\cal F}^{\prime}}){\cal K}(r)\;,

div.p: with â„±23â€²â¢(r)=â„±23â¢(r+c(1))subscriptsuperscriptâ„±â€²23ğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ„±23ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘1caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:23 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) RELOP:equals caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:23 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r ADDOP:plus italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:){\cal F}^{\prime}_{23}(r)={\cal F}_{23}(r+c^{(1)}), as a consequence of

Finally

Moreover, (6.8) together with (6.5) show that ğ’Ÿâ¢YrFğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ¹caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{F}} and ğ’Ÿâ¢YrVâ¢6ğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘Ÿğ‘‰6caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6}} are the same quasi-Hopf algebra.
